Internships have provided me with unparalleled exposure to the real-world application of software engineering principles. They allowed me to bridge the gap between theory and practice, providing hands-on experience in coding, problem-solving, and working in teams. The fast-paced, dynamic nature of these environments pushed me to develop new skills, adapt quickly to different technologies, and contribute to meaningful projects. The challenges I encountered during my internships gave me insight into industry trends, helping me refine my academic goals and career aspirations. Through these experiences, I developed a deeper passion for software engineering, particularly in areas like software development, system architecture, and coding efficiency.

Mentorship programs have been another critical factor in my career development. Having access to experienced professionals who offered guidance and advice allowed me to navigate the complexities of the software engineering industry with greater clarity. My mentors helped me identify my strengths and areas for improvement, encouraged me to pursue challenging opportunities, and gave me valuable feedback on my projects. Their insights on both technical skills and career planning have been instrumental in helping me make informed decisions about the direction of my academic journey and career.

University coursework also played a significant role in shaping my career. Courses in data structures, algorithms, software design, and computer systems provided the theoretical foundation for my work as a software engineer. In particular, project-based courses that mimicked real-world scenarios gave me the chance to apply my knowledge and collaborate with peers. The combination of rigorous coursework and collaborative projects helped me gain a solid understanding of core concepts, equipping me with the skills I needed to succeed in internships and, later, in the workplace.

Job shadowing and career fairs offered additional perspectives, enabling me to explore different career paths within software engineering. Observing professionals in action during job shadowing experiences allowed me to better understand the day-to-day responsibilities and workflows in various roles, from software developers to system analysts. Career fairs introduced me to potential employers, exposing me to a range of companies and technologies, and helping me gauge what different organizations expect from software engineers.

The encouragement and support of my family and friends have been crucial throughout this process. Their belief in my abilities has kept me motivated during challenging times and inspired me to persevere through difficult academic and professional milestones.

column23:
Internships and Work-Based Learning

    Industry-Specific Internships: Expanding opportunities for students to intern with local businesses, NGOs, and government agencies would provide hands-on experience in their fields of study. Partnerships with various industries can also offer students tailored internships in fields like agriculture, tech, healthcare, and education.
    Short-Term Work Placements: Not all students are able to commit to long-term internships, so offering shorter-term placements (e.g., 2–3 weeks) can expose students to work environments without the time commitment of a full internship.

2. Professional Networking Events

    Career Fairs and Job Expos: Organizing regular career fairs and job expos where students can meet employers directly and explore job opportunities is essential. Bringing a mix of local and international companies would give students diverse options for their careers.
    Industry Networking Nights: Hosting networking nights where students can engage with alumni, professionals, and potential employers in an informal setting could help students develop professional relationships and gain insight into industry trends.
    Panel Discussions and Guest Speakers: Bringing in industry experts and successful alumni to speak about their career journeys and the future of their sectors can offer valuable learning experiences and inspiration.
column25:
Industry Collaboration and Networking Opportunities

    Partnerships with Industry: Universities should strengthen ties with local and international businesses to provide students with internship opportunities, job placements, and real-world insights. These partnerships could also lead to career fairs, guest lectures, and networking events featuring industry professionals.
    Alumni Networks: Building and actively maintaining alumni networks can provide valuable mentorship and career advice for current students. Alumni can also act as bridges between the university and potential employers.

2. Career Counseling and Personalized Support

    Tailored Career Counseling: Many students may not be aware of the full range of career options available to them. Offering personalized career counseling based on individual skills, interests, and academic strengths could guide students more effectively toward suitable career paths.
    Regular Career Assessments: Providing students with tools like personality assessments or career aptitude tests could help identify their strengths and align them with potential career options.

3. Skills Development and Job Readiness

    Soft Skills Training: While technical skills are essential, many employers also prioritize soft skills like communication, leadership, teamwork, and time management. Universities could offer workshops, seminars, and training sessions to help students improve these essential skills.
    Resume Building & Interview Preparation: Offering specialized workshops on resume writing, cover letter creation, and mock interview sessions can help students feel more confident and prepared when applying for jobs.

4. Job Market Insights and Career Guidance Materials

    Market Research and Data: Providing up-to-date information on job market trends in Ethiopia and globally, including emerging industries, salary ranges, and in-demand skills, would help students make informed career choices.
    Job Search Resources: Developing a centralized online portal or database where students can find job opportunities, internships, and career resources could make the job search process more organized and efficient.

5. Entrepreneurship and Freelancing Support

    Entrepreneurship Guidance: Given the limited availability of formal jobs in some sectors, universities could offer resources and support for students interested in starting their own businesses or working in the gig economy.
    Freelancer Networks: Creating networks for students interested in freelancing could allow them to connect with clients and other freelancers, as well as access resources to improve their work.

the accelerated academic schedule that has significantly impacted the quality of our

educational standards nationwide, we feel that immediate intervention is required to

graduates from our institution are well-equipped to contribute meaningfully to
Ethiopia’s development.

future students.

Addis Ababa University invites various agents to participate in student career development programs and job fairs. After registering all graduating class students, these agents classify the students into different categories for their own purposes. Companies that hire students through these agents may not be paying the correct taxes to the government. The taxes deducted from employees' gross salaries are often paid to the agents, who benefit from this arrangement. Additionally, universities are not actively supervising agents during the student registration process or monitoring where they place students. The government is also neglecting to oversee agents and the labor conditions of students.

It is recommended that universities and the government take steps to address these issues. Agents should not be intermediaries for student employment. Companies should directly advertise job openings on their official websites and recruit students directly from universities. Moreover, university career development officers should prioritize student grades and academic records when selecting students for job placements, rather than relying on personal factors.

By implementing these changes, universities can ensure that students are treated fairly and that the government is receiving the appropriate taxes.
